cards.definition: The Medieval period, also known as the Middle Ages, lasted from about 500 to 1500.
Charlemagne, or Charles the Great, was a Frankish ruler who built an empire across France, Germany, and part of Italy around 800.
In 800, Pope Leo III crowned Charlemagne 'emperor,' reviving the idea of a united Christian community.
Officials sent out by Charlemagne to check on roads, listen to grievances, and see that justice was done.
Charlemagne's empire was divided into three regions by the Treaty of Verdun in 843.
A loosely organized system of rule in which powerful local lords divided their landholdings among lesser lords.
Lesser lords who pledged service and loyalty to the greater lord in exchange for land.
An estate granted by a lord to a vassal, which could range from a few acres to hundreds of square miles.
Vassals owed their lords 40 days of military service each year.
A vassal usually had a liege lord to whom he owed his first loyalty.
The lowest class in feudal society, working the land for the lords.
Castles were built for defense, not comfort.
Castles had walls, arrow loops, drawbridges, and towers.
Some castles had watchtowers close to towns, where torches were lit to signal threats.
Knights were mounted warriors who trained from boyhood.
Training began at age seven, with the boy learning to ride and fight.
At about 21, a knight was dubbed, taking his place beside other warriors.
Knights used chainmail in the early medieval ages.
Knights used plate armor in later medieval ages.
Fighting started to decrease after the 1100s, leading knights to participate in jousting tournaments.
A code of conduct that required knights to be brave, loyal, true to their word, generous to their enemies, and protective of women.
A lesser lord who pledged loyalty and service to a more powerful lord in exchange for land (a fief).
An estate or land granted by a lord to a vassal in exchange for loyalty and service.
Peasants bound to the land who were not free, could not leave without permission, worked on the lord's land, and received the lord's protection.
Harsh, long work hours, short life expectancy (~35 years), dwellings often one-room huts made of wood or straw, sometimes including livestock.
Powerful lords who held large fiefs; noblewomen ran the manor while lords were away.
Priests, monks, and nuns who were responsible for religious life and devoted themselves to spiritual goals.
People who lived in monasteries and convents, taking vows of poverty, chastity, and obedience, while providing social services.
Centers of learning where monks and nuns worked, preserved ancient writings, and provided social services.
A powerful organization that unified Western Europe, shaping medieval life with the Pope as its spiritual leader.
The spiritual leader of the Catholic Church, head of the Papal States, who claimed authority over secular rulers.
The body of laws established by the Catholic Church, governing religious teachings, behavior, and morals.
A Church tax equal to a tenth of a person's income.
Refers to worldly matters rather than spiritual; the Church was the most powerful secular force in Western Europe.
The most severe Church penalty for disobedience, banning an individual from the sacraments and Church community.
A Church punishment excluding an entire town, region, or kingdom from most sacraments.
The lord's estate, the heart of the medieval economy, a self-sufficient world where peasants produced most of what they needed.
Included a village, water mill, church, and a manor house.
A large estate with fields, rivers, forts, vineyards, orchards, blacksmiths, mills, graveyards, gallows, and barns.
Divided into strips with one field left fallow each year to restore soil fertility.
Associations of people with the same trade or craft, such as weavers, bakers, and sword makers.
To join a guild, one had to serve as an apprentice for several years, often starting at age seven or eight.
Institutions arising from the need for educated clergy, literate rulers, and skilled middle-class professionals.
A written document outlining the rights and privileges of a town, often granted by a lord or king.
Centers of trade and handicraft that grew with revived trade, offering opportunities for serfs to gain freedom.
Use of money, borrowing, and investing led to banking and weakened serfdom.
The Church's set of laws governing religious doctrine, clergy conduct, and moral issues.
A secular legal system, indicating a plan to create a unified legal code and use juries/courts.
A charter forced upon the English monarch by nobles, recognizing their rights and ensuring the monarch must obey laws.
A plague from the Middle East that reached Europe via trading ships, killing 1/3 of the population and causing societal upheaval.
The head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States, believed to have authority over secular rulers.
Gothic churches with large naves, relics, sculptures, rose windows, spires, and flying buttresses.
A knightly code emphasizing bravery, loyalty, honesty, and protection of the weak, especially women.
A social hierarchy with the monarch at the top, followed by upper lords, lower lords, knights, and serfs at the bottom.
Efforts to increase power by maintaining good relations with the Pope, building armies, expanding courts, and efficient taxation.
